newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Eleven North Koreans shot to death in South Korea.
newsitem.headline: Eleven North Koreans shot to death in South Korea.

text.p: Eleven North Koreans who landed in the enemy South from a submarine were found dead on Wednesday, possibly shot by one of their number who also used the gun on himself, a defence ministry spokesman said.
A 12th was captured alive after a massive search while another eight or nine were still at large, the spokesman said.
Authorities described the North Koreans as infiltrators, and angrily denounced the incident as a breach of an armistice agreement that ended the 1950-53 Korean War.
"One of the dead infiltrators had a gun on him and we think he killed himself after shooting the others," the spokesman told a news conference.

The captured North Korean, Lee Kang-soo, 31, gave a different account, telling interrogators the submarine drifted into South Korean waters after developing engine trouble, television news reports said.
Lee said the vessel left port in North Korea on Monday and began drifting the following day, Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation news reported.
The submarine was spotted by a taxi driver soon after midnight on Tuesday. It was stranded on rocks nine kilometres (5.6 miles) south of the east coast city of Kangnung.
Authorities said it apparently hit a reef while returning to the North after dropping off infiltrators on a beach.
But there was also speculation the submarine could have been sent to pick up an agent or drop off a small unit of spies -- and the mission then went badly wrong.
The 11 dead North Koreans were found on top of a mountain dressed in jeans and sneakers, the defence spokesman said.
Authorities believed a total of around 20 North Koreans landed on a beach south of the border with North Korea. That was double their initial estimate.
On board were automatic weapons and ammunition, along with canned food and shoes.

Thousands of troops and police using sniffer dogs combed terrain around the beach as helicopters roared overhead. They set up checkpoints on all main roads. Naval vessels and a reconnaissance plane joined the search.
As night fell, a curfew was clamped on the area and security forces formed a cordon. The curfew will be lifted at first light on Thursday.
"This incident is a grave provocation and a definite infiltration against South Korea by North Korea," the director of operations at the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Kim Dong-shin, told a news conference.

Cabinet ministers who deal with Security-related matters held a meeting chaired by Unification Minister Kwon O-kie and declared the infiltration "a direct threat to our national security", a unification ministry statement said.

Yonhap news agency quoted a former North Korean commando, captured while on a mission to kill South Korea's president in 1968, as saying the submarine may have been planning to bring home a Pyongyang agent.
"The submarine may have hit rocks by mistake and then all members of the crew fled onto land after finding it impossible to go back," Kim Shin-jo was quoted as saying.
Adding weight to this speculation were signs of panic flight, with weapons and ammunition abandoned in the boat and personal belongings scattered along a road.

Wednesday's drama was one of the most deadly since 1968 when 31 North Koreans reached the presidential Blue House in Seoul. Twenty-eight were killed in a gunbattle in which 34 Southern troops, police and civilians also died.

Shin Sang-kil, deputy head of operations of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters troops found a machinegun with 75 rounds of ammunition, a Soviet-made rifle with 100 bullets and 75 other bullets on the vessel.
A written pledge of loyalty to North Korean leader Kim Jong-il was also found. Military clothing, keys and a life jacket were recovered on a nearby road.

The defence ministry said the Sang-o class submarine measured 34 metres (111 ft) in length and weighed 330 tonnes. North Korea has about 10 of these submarines, each capable of carrying 21 people, a ministry official said.
Television pictures showed the grey vessel bobbing helplessly in the water.
